text: my name is cheapo Chung I'm an actress
by profession and an activist the rest
of the time my family came from China to
Africa in 1904 I spent my first couple
of years and Mozambique in refugee camps
with my mum who was working there and
then most of my childhood was in
Zimbabwe during its most idyllic phase
belonging is a difficult question for
all the aspirins belonging I think is is
something that is in one's mind you know
if you choose to belong then then you do
I grew up in a Chinese family so
ethnically in many ways identify as
Chinese Zimbabwe as my home the Chinese
community were very kind to me and
totally accepted me the only experience
I had was with kids my age because kids
are less polite and much more
straightforward so my cousin's used to
call me infectious I come from a family
of black sheeps my mum was a radical I
have always been confused as to how a
mother of a very young child I was four
or five months old when she took me into
a war zone how you do that what was
wonderful about my background was that
because I was a mixed race I've always
been on the margins and been an outsider
there is something quite powerful about
that role by not having too much of
attachment to any one group it means
that you're someone who can go between I
think it's that ability when you don't
absolutely belong in one society you
have to be something of a chameleon and
be able to adapt yourself
was quite strategic about how how to
make it in London or how to establish
myself and that was by going to the
Royal Academy of Dramatic Art which is
to go to a British institution and
coorporate myself there and use that as
a platform to enter society I often feel
Envy of my colleagues who I went to
school with who are male and many of
them are white and most of them are more
successful than I am because within
theatre there are just more parts for
men and it's more likely that you'll be
understood if you're white if I were to
come back again in another life I
wouldn't want to come back as anything
but a woman I would love to have a safer
world a more peaceful world and a world
where the feminine way of doing things
are talking of dialoguing of creating
change is much more than norm and not
something out of this world and
different
